comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Presumably taken as part of same series as www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/3029426027/ and www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/3030260446/ , which have date 4/26/13 written on. I assume comment by dingey sexton on latter photo is the explanation for what is going on. As an illustrator, he used the mannequin instead of a live model. From what I've read, he would have thoroughly enjoyed the fact that people find the image disturbing!!!

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content: Thanks to all for the interest in this series of photographs.  We will add James Montgomery Flagg's full name to the source data and then reload the description to Flickr.

comment._content: he was also the reason for the Army's "don't ask, don't tell" policy

comment._content: This picture is pretty odd the way they have a manikin on here crying and the way he is trying to console her

comment.author: 87724873@N00
comment._content: It was common for illustrators to use mannequins as reference. However... this is truly an odd picture. Flagg must have had a sense of humor.
